Can analog recorded music be manipulated by an analog oscilloscope? If so, how's it done?

It's parameter automation which is more like an xy plot where x is time and y is the parameter magnitude. So it changes the variable as the graph plays from left to right. Key frames are like the start and finish points on the graph and the automation is the transition  between those points. This however works independently of key frames if you want to experiment.

So basically this is what we also do with lasershow projectors? A signal drives two actuators that steer a beam and draws a pattern, combined with the blanking of the signal at certain moments. Repeating this fast enough and it will draw you an animation. I’ve been playing a hit with such lasers and the thing is that the physical actuators (the stepper motors with the mirrors attached) are a limiting factor because they physically need to move from point a to point b. The more complex an animation becomes, the more visible this is (for example) at corners of objects. On this scope the picture is drawn without the use of physical moving objects/mirrors and therefor I guess these very complex Tetris animations with razor sharp corners are possible.

I guess that you could translate the laser projector files into audio and you would end up with similar music. Nevertheless, very cool and fun to watch such retro equipment bring used like this. 🤟🏻

Ok where do I start? I watch a lot of science channels and have enjoyed a few of your videos. This is over the top! As a guy who started going to Grateful Dead shows in the 1970s, I've long known how math can create amazing visualizations by pumping audio into assorted math concepts like fractals. I'm also a musician who was lucky enough to get about 10 hours with a mini-moog in the mid-1970s and began to understand the relationship between what you see on the oscilloscope and music. Recently I was looking for efficient FFT algorithms for some neopixel LED animations I am experimenting with. My research caused YouTube's suggestion algorithm to recommend a number of videos 1b1b's FFT explainer. Then I saw this and thought "hmm, that sounds cool." Cool is an understatement. This is simply amazing. I am going to check out their website and find ways to support their music. I do maker hacking for fun and often mix analog and digital concepts. This has generated a dozen ideas within minutes after watching. I am going to share this broadly!!! Thank you sir. I am now a subscriber.

I am an electronics engineer with over 25 years experience. This is a complete inappropriate way of using and oscilloscope. Dustin, I just found this video today. You made me go to my lab closet, get out my Tek 475 that I bought new about 30 years ago and just give it a little hug :-) In the years i've had it, absolutely nothing has been done to it. I have a scope calibrator. I check the scope once a year. Not only is the beam within specs, it's on the reticle line! No replacing caps, no calibrations, no nothing. Let's see the chicom junk still be working in 30 years. Oh, one other thing. Tek's bandwidth rating is the maximum frequency that the scope is still within specs. The chicom manufactures specify the bandwidth as when the trace is down 3db or by half.

I have an alarm set in my phone's calendar that reminds me every 6 months to get the scope out and turn it on to make sure the caps stay formed.

I admit to using a Rigol 4 channel 200 MHz digital scope. I'd rather be using a Tek or Agilent but I'm retired now and on a fixed budget.

To be clear he wasn't doing a Fourier transform.  You could think of it as a way to visualize a fourier transform, but thats not what he was doing.  He had two waves one was descending while the other one was oscillating as a cosine function and then when it got to the bottom they switched and the first wave stated oscilating as sun while the other one started ascending.  The whole time the waves were discrete signals, so you don't need to perform a fourier transform to split them out

I have a patent pending on sound source location technology using a similar principle. If you orient microphones with a specific geometry, the same sounds will interfere with itself in predictable ways as they will arrive at each microphone with a time-shift. This creates constructive and destructive interference when the signals are combined. The nature of that interference is directly related to the orientation of the sound source in relation to a microphone array.

Programmers secret.
You don't need to be great at math to be a good programmer. It's more logical problem solving and troubleshooting.

The only time you need more than basic arithmetic is when you are doing numerical simulations. Even then, the amount of needed math can very directly with how accurate you want the sim to be. Because good programmers can find alternatives to math by using clever conditional statements.

He even mentions algorithms which does not imply a lot of math, it implies conditional statements.

The mathematician in me says you should try drawing some Hilbert Curves on the oscilloscope.   Also 3brown1blue has some amazing visualizations of Fourier Transforms with a very intuitive explanation.    The pitch of the image sounded like it was largely based on the refresh rate, especially for simple shapes, which Intuit’s that we don’t differentiate so much the shape of the image based on the sound, rather our ear differentiate how often it’s redrawn. If you can set the pitch for an image by adjusting the refresh I see how you can string them into melodies.   The music need some drum beats, but the impulse nature of a drum beat, scatters the image.   Fundamentally pulses are tone poor, but time precise.

I wonder if you could turn something like this into a wearable device. A camera always focusing a specific area in front of you and the headphones giving you a specific audio representation of the environment as a stereo coded signal. Compared to seeing (gathering visual data) the data resolution one could read out via hearing would of course be limited (missing one whole dimension and essentially being monochromatic).
Now, I really wonder if one could train a brain (or machine for that matter) to get a sense of its surrounding this way. If it could it could be a kind of glasses for the blind. Bending the light/information in a way so that a nervous system with a more limited range of input could be "made to see" like this.
Now, I really really wonder if, if the first two cases worked, if you could improve healthy perception like this too. Could you, for example, introduce new ranges of say, the electromagnetic spectrum to our perceptive apparatus? Say, "hearing" if something emitted certain wavelengths beyond the visual spectrum. Like real X-ray vision!

Re the first part - I did this in high school in the early 1970s.  My lab partner and I hooked up two frequency wave generators, one to the vertical and one to the horizontal, to the oscilloscope and were able to create sine waves, rotating 'atoms' and all kinds of other things.  Then, we built a speaker tower... we mounted front-surface mirrors onto the speakers and mounted the speakers so that a laser beam would be reflected from the x-axis to the z-axis by the first speaker mirror (from horizontal to vertical) then reflect off the second speaker mirror to go from the z- to the y-axis (back to horizontal but perpendicular from its original direction) onto a wall.  We were able to duplicate the oscilloscope patterns on the wall with the laser.  Then, we took the wave generators off and just hooked up our stereo.  We were the most popular nerds in school.

It seems like it's more amazing if you think of it as taking a sound and turning it into a visual, because that seems surprising. But I imagine the most efficient way to do this is to create the image and then backtrack what the math would be for that given line, and then stack the lines forward to create multiples of it. Like what's the X and Y here? Loudness? Pitch? So if you want your point to be a (2,0) does that mean 2 Hrtz and 0 Hrtz? Or 2 decibles and 0 decibles? Or what? In any case, it seems like once you demystify that part, it's kind of simple. But does the sound cancel itself out (in which case the math is a lot more complex?)?

It's beautiful, but in a way not very surprising that doubling the T Rex's over and over would make beautiful sounds. The series of notes you heard was the harmonic series. If you took any percussive sound and doubled its frequency over and over you'd get the same thing. Adam Neely did something like this a while back on his channel.

I'm a little confused by how the original images are made, though. Are the sounds canceling each other out and creating the end percussive sound for the larger image? That seems like what's going on, but I don't understand that as well as I feel like I understand what's going on when the smaller T Rex's are made.

People have been playing with oscilloscopes like this for decades but never to this level.

Here is the thought.

If you can translate sound to monochrome video, then you can translate monochrome video to sound. If you can do that and achieve the resolution necessary for actual optic scanning of the surroundings and transfer from the generated picture to the sound waves which would be used to display these on an oscilloscope, then you can "teach" the brain to read this sonic input and generate "visual" imagery based upon it.

When I was at Georgia Tech in the late '80s/early '90s, one of my electrical engineering labs dealt with TTL logic gates. One of our projects was to draw shapes on an oscilloscope using the output of a TTL circuit we had designed.  We had specific shapes we were required to draw for each "step" of the project, and we had to do it with a minimum number of chips.  I thought that was the coolest thing I'd ever seen on an oscilloscope.  Until I saw this video.  😊   What they do is totally amazing!  Wow!

When I was in junior high school back in 1973-74 a man came to my school, and we had an “assembly “, meaning, the teachers wanted to show us all something cool that wasn’t part of the curriculum. He did all sorts of fascinating stuff with sound, and part of it was on the oscilloscope. He played recordings of pure tones sung by an opera singer, and then he played a short recording of art and music that he had made combining these tones. It was a beautiful interplay of rings in 3D within the oscilloscope. I’ve never forgotten it.

Nice evolution of waveform  music.  I used a Tek 465b Oscilloscope (with the DM44 Digital Mutimeter integrated on top) to visualize music in the 1980's, it had 2 channel input, A and B delayed triggering with an external Z-input on the back. Used a Moog Synthesizer for inputs which was fun.  Also, you should try using an old 1968 vinyl synth recording called "Switched on Bach" (Walter Carlos) for a new input to look at and have fun with, all recorded with Moog tracks, creates the most amazing geometrical patterns, I guarantee it will amaze you.  I still have my Tek 465b, and it still works like a champ :-)  Once in a while I bring it out to make audio patterns with. Thanks for sharing and helping to expand and keep this medium alive.  We can all learn from vibrations and patterns.

The old CRT TV/Monitors are actually Oscilloscopes with the x, y input fed from a sine wave generator and the signal controlling the intensity of the beam. So, you get fine-control over the image on the display using just one serial signal.

I've talked about this before for analog vector / oscilloscope art: The faster the beam moves, the brighter the beam needs to be, to see a large complex image clearly. BUT if the beam is not moving, the beam has to be turned down, or the electrons will burn the phosphors from too much power. So in addition to X-Y coordinate signals, there needs to be a third Z signal to control beam intensity (not just beam on/off control).

Hey Destin,

There are a lot of similarities with the laser light show system I developed in the 80's. I understand what they are doing and consider it some pretty simple stuff, but several things put together in a very sophisticated way. I never went as far to change update rates to get musical effects with a clock rate just under 1 MHz... YES! ONE MEGAHERTZ clock.
The system I used was really stretched in processor time to do real-time rotations, scaling and motions of multiple images at once for choreography to recorded music.
..
Makes me wish I hadn't sold my primary development system to someone who hasn't done anything with it yet... but time marches on and life has it priorities...
....
Also, one of my best features was what I called my circle generator like the one shown at 12 minutes. By allowing the operator to put in any "crazy" numbers for the horizontal and vertical frequency and size steps you can get some of the most complex figures that look NOTHING like the common Lissajous patterns. Some of the patterns were logical given sine and cosine, but others were most certainly caused by the limitations on the trig algorithm in the software's math package.
Stepping the sine and cosine correctly you can not only get any polygon, but five pointed stars and. in fact, any number of star-points you wish. Entering crazy numbers yielded some of the most interesting pseudo-animation image motions. I have a Laser projector running a ROM that I bring out on Halloween that has a 13 minute show of my best "circle Generator" images/pseudo-animations.
..
I started to add key frame animation (the computer does the Tweening for you) , but things were changing in life and I had to do the research to figure out how to do it, but had to write the book I needed to know how to do it (Piecewise Polynomial Interpolation Fundamentals)
..

Also. I've seen YouTube videos of systems that produced relatively normal sounding music, but with O-Scope mages virtually hidden in it and not affecting the music that I could hear; which was quite impressive. This music has the classical "square wave timbre" because they do quite a bit of location jumps.
Cheers

I used to put a 60 Hz sine wave into both the horizontal and vertical inputs and delay the phase at the horizontal input via an RC network to produce an ellipse. I'd then add a higher frequency square wave to only the vertical input to produce what resembled the top of a castle tower. You could then vary the frequency of the square wave to make the top of the castle tower rotate in either direction. If you have acces to an oscilloscope and audio generators you may want to try this.
You should definitely use the sound of smarter every day as the new intro.

I think we've just discovered a lot about why sound design works on humans (and other mammals and birds to a lesser extent).

Our brains can SEE THIS structure in the audio. That's why we love audio and music so much.

Also, literally how I think consciousness works in general: I believe consciousness mainly boils down to the ability to convert arbitrary-dimensional perception into 1D audio-like signals using wave mechanics in our brains. The ability to project chaos down to a 1D signal is the key.

By neurons growing into differently sized loops connected in different ways, they can resonate at different frequencies. The way they connect to each other determines phases and interference. The combination of these things gives you everything you need to do signal processing. And signal processing ==> thought.

When I was a kid, I manage to get top grade at my physics lesson by doing some roughly similar (but way much simpler) "picture from sound" scope trick.

Before an upcoming practical, the physics teacher dared us to manage to display a "6" (which is the best grade in the grading system here around) on scope, and we would get that grade if we manage to display it.

I haven't seen the scope before hand. But because we we're supposed to display a figure, I guessed we were supposed to use the X-Y mode of the scope.
That evening, I typed some code on my home computer, generated proper data, piped it to my sound blaster and recorded it on a tape (it was a long time ago - I couldn't afford a CD burner back then), and brought a walkman and some cabling for the practicals.
Indeed, we did use the X-Y during the practical (mostly displaying circles, ovals and lines with in- or out-of-phase sine-waves for the actual practicals' exercises). End of the lab practicals, comes the time to show the teacher's dare. I take out my contraption and manage to frankenstein a way to plug it into the scope.
I personally was a bit disappointed by the final result: turns out there was way too much filtering happening along my audio chain (at the soundcard's output, at the tape recorder, and now at my walkman's output) so the shape on screen wasn't as sharp as I hoped. But the teacher and his TAs was impressed by the attempt and me and my lab mate got the grade.

What the teacher actually expected from the student? Turns out the scope had dual lasers and dual Y input. The teacher was expecting us to simply apply what we've seen during the practical, and generate a circle by having the usual "90°" out-of-phase sine-wave on X-Y mode on the first laser, and then simply give an in-phase Y2 input for the second laser's X-Y2 giving a straight line. Align both on screen, you get the 6 figure.

I was way too creative and overthinking with my recorder. Geeks' life.
Still managed to impress with my single laser contrived solution.

A vector monitor or vector display is a display device used for computer graphics up through the 1970s. It is a type of CRT, similar to that of an early oscilloscope. In a vector display, the image is composed of drawn lines rather than a grid of glowing pixels as in raster graphics. - See the Wiki article about "Vector monitor".

Back in mid 80s, I used to perform live laser light shows. We used a real to real tape play because it could use 4 channels. 2 of the channels were the right and left audio and the other 2 channels were the 2 images that would be drawn by the laser. They used an oscilloscope to create the images, then recorded on tape and play back using the laser beam passing a prism to 4 colored beams. These beams was passed across mirrors controlled by servos.

At my first job out of college in 1979, I worked in a biomedical research lab.  I worked with MDs, PhDs, and Post-Grads.  Among the gobs of (then) state of the art electronics, we had an obligatory Tektronix oscilloscope as well as a hand-built Cromemco Z-80.  I don't recall the Cromemco as having a hard drive, but it did have two 5-1/4" floppy drives and the thing ran on BASIC.  Anyhow, one of the post-docs and I became buds.  During down times in the lab he taught me to use BASIC.  At some point he connected the Cromemco to the oscilloscope and showed me how to use trig functions with BASIC-controlled sequential variables to make interesting patterns on the 'scope.  Obviously, making squiggles on the 'scope wasn't the focus of our work there, but it did help with my basic BASIC programming as well as my appreciation of trig.

Back in the early seventies, I read an article in an electronics magazine about Lisajous patterns. I was fascinated by it, and I created my own budget Lisajous generator...I took an old black & white TV (CRT, of course) and cut the wires going to the yoke on the neck of the CRT. I connected outputs from a stereo to the yoke--one audio channel drove the horizontal beam sweep, and the other audio channel drove the vertical beam sweep. It was very cool to listen to the radio while watching that. The beam was (of course) in perfect sync with the audio, so a bass beat would jump all over the screen and a speaking voice put a circular pattern in the center that looked something like a mouth. It reminded me of an old part of the Captain Kangaroo show where he had a talking character (I cannot remember that character's name--it was over 50 years ago!) that was a Lisajous pattern on a TV screen. It was a lot of fun and easy and cheap to do. Thanks for the memories!

btw: Blender is 100% free and open source, and you can download it right now (Windows, Mac, Linux, doesn't matter!) and play with it. There are channels out there dedicated to teaching you how to use Blender, starting from absolutely zero knowledge of what 3D modelling is, all the way to experts who want to learn more about a specific obscure topic.


I recommend Blender Guru as a starting point. There are too many good blender tutorials to count. Just look for them!

What sort of sorcery is this?

The ingenious part is to think about using oscilloscope in such a way. Making it real is actually easy. Drawing shapes with sound on oscilloscope is a few day project or few hours if you know the math and don't have to search for publications. Harder part is to make sound pitch a variable when drawing given shape, but still shouldn't be that hard.


If I were doing something like this, I would start with a software to draw vector animation or even use regular video files/streams like avi, mp4, mkv etc. as an input, so any video editing software or graphics, animation, modelling could be used.


Then I would work on an algorithm that would encode image as a noise within any given sound stream, so any DAW could be used to make music.


This would be easier and more powerful, but not as magical as an artists who is merging sound and images in the same time.


On the other hand this is just reinventing the wheel. Good old CRT TVs were just modified, more advanced oscilloscopes designed to display images, where electron beam scanned screen from left to right, from top to bottom.


First video games found in arcades often used vector screen, that was an oscilloscope with hardware that would draw lines at given location.


All I'm saying that you shouldn't be intimidated by such technology. Math it's not hard and you can find everything online. It's really great what these guys are doing, but everyone can do similar stuff with everything that surrounds us.

When the guy is live-coding the sine and co-sine (11:40) he's also using Max on top of Ableton Live. If you want a free version of that (with a somewhat less friendly interface, granted, but still graphical), go for Pure Data (Pd).


The sounds themselves that they use are not that complicated to make (I mean: making sounds that sound just like those is kinda easy). The awesome thing here is making sure your two channels actually interact the way you want according to a totally non-musical rule, while still maintaining sound quality and uniformity.


A similar thing, entirely digital this time, is people using pictures as the spectrograph of a sound and building the actual sound from there. So when you play it you get a kind of scrolling movie if you watch the spectral analysis go by.

Go find an old arcade version of "Asteroids", take the video signal and put it through an audio amp and you will hear similar sounds. The images on the 'O' scope are technically called vector graphics . This video just prompted me to spend several hours playing with VCV Rack - an open source program that simulates a modular synthesizer. VCV has an oscilloscope "device" that can operate just like the scope in the video, with a 'X" and 'Y' axis input and external trigger. It's limited in speed to audio frequencies, 0 to 20khz, but these patterns and images are mostly generated with Low Freq Oscilators. The only thing the VCV scope lacks is a "blanking" input which makes drawing separate objects or shapes without a connecting trace impossible. The really cool thing is that you have unlimited number of 'O' scopes, so you can see the shape of the X, Y, and trigger signals separately, and begin to understand, first, how complex the program designed by these guys actually is, and second, how our ears are incredible devices that can detect minute, mathematical differences in two combined wave forms.

While this was super cool, my brain has a civil war going on, because it wouldn't believe there is a chance Destin has forgotten there was something called CRT and analog oscilloscopes are just the same and they exactly can manage the point of ray using that x/y inputs. these geniuses are sending screen scan signals as sound (which is turned then in regular electrical controlled magnetic signals in TV and CRT). The genius part of their work is that plugin and programming algorithms to "simply" mix and modulate shapes into the sound they need to create the shapes.

I can understand you are excited, but this former part is done even before eighties, those poor guys just didn't have digital sound and computers and Blender etc. :)) They did it by analog signals which are not very exactly controllable.

I've had an idea, though it doesn't translate well to the display art, and may not actually be possible with the current programs. Typical audio is 1 dimensional, with left (-X>0) and right (0<X), but what if you broke this out into surround sound, or a plane, with back (-Y>0) and front (0<Y)? Take it a step further with newer 3d audio technology and have down (-Z>0) and up (0<Z).




Of course, all of this gets very, very messy with higher dimensions. Such as 2d audio needing 4 scope inputs, meaning 4 mathematical dimensions; 3d would require 6. Basically Y=X*2.
It gets even messier when you factor in that they're using a 3d model to produce a 2d scene to produce a 1d audio source. But how would this work for higher audio dimensions? Is a singular dimension tacked onto the end all that is needed, Z=Y+1? 5d model>4d scene>2d audio, 7d model>6d scene>3d audio? Or does each pair of dimensions need an additional dimension added to it, Z=Y+X or Z=3X? 6d model>4d scene>2d audio, 9d model>6d scene>3d audio?


I'm not even sure if Blender can handle higher dimensions, not that anyone could actually comprehend the higher dimensional polyhedra, like a 5d cube, let alone a 9d cube.
Their own program's side of things would be easier, though, as the original is taking a 2d scene and translating it to 2 inputs the scope can produce an image with, X/Y > inputs 1/2, all it would need to do is expand for more mathematical dimensions and inputs, X/Y\Z/A\B/C > inputs 1/2\3/4\5/6. Of course, following this scheme would require three independent scopes to make it function correctly on the scope side of things. Not that the physical scopes are relevant at this point, just the scene to input translation is.
Then assuming Blender, or another program, can actually do higher dimensions, producing a picture should be fairly easy to do also, as we do have 2d interpretations of hypercubes by going from 4d to 3d slices to 2d slices. It would just take more work for higher dimensions. This final picture would be the display art side of things.


Though, with 3d tech, we could skip the last 2d slice step in certain use cases. Either with 3d glasses, newer trickery by using a glass pyramid to reflect multiple images into a single 'hologram', or with newer tech like the Looking Glass display. Edge case, yes, but it'd still be cool.

Lissajous figures for the win.

Way back in the late seventies I did something similar. I opened up an old 25" black-and-white television set and connected the horizontal and vertical yoke windings to a 20 watt tube-type stereo amplifier I found at a garage sale. Come to think of it, that's also where I got the TV. Anyway, each channel was driven by a separate 12-bit DAC (digital to analog converter) built on a prototype board in an Apple ][ microcomputer. Essentially it was a primitive oscilloscope, only using electromagnetic deflection, not electrostatic (as true oscilloscope tubes do.)

The DACs were controlled by a simple assembler-language routine that continually dumped the contents of two data tables to the DACs (one for the X axis, the other for the Y) as fast as possible, and would slowly shift the phase relationship between the two tables to generate dynamic Lissajous figures. The nifty thing was that I wasn't limited to a few simple waveforms from a function generator, we had a lot of fun using Apple Floating Point BASIC programs to poke all sorts of interesting data to the display.

Years ago I used to work in the Laser Lightshow business. My boss was one of, if not the inventor of the Laser Light Rock show. When he started out he had to do the math on paper and program cast-off IBM computers with punchcards to do this (this is back in the 70s). The point is, the output goals were pretty much the same - pure X/Y coordinate data over time. These are parallel disciplines that use very similar techniques.
In the early 90s I used to hand draw line-art animations, frame by frame, and the software I used would output the X/Y data to a laser projector, which used 2 servos with mirrors (one for X and one for Y) to draw the animation with the laser. The interesting thing is that if you got your ear close to the servos, you could hear the sound of drawing being generated by the servos in the same way the oscilloscope is doing.
What I'm particularly intrigued by is that you should be able to work backwards from those laser-shows to generate music from their data. You could also do this with any old vector graphic video games, like asteroids or star-wars, and hear what they sounded like being played. In fact I once played a game of asteroids, with a laser projector, on the side of the Nations Bank building in downtown Dallas, doing just that. Fun times.

Can you program it to play Pong (without a computer)?
The 1939 World's Fair had the world's first video game, which was an oscilliscope programmed to play Pong. The inventor didn't think it was important and dismantled it afterward. In the 1970s there was a major lawsuit over the copyright to the game and they rebuilt the original machine as evidence that it predated the supposed copyrighted version.

Back in the mid to late 70's Popular Electronics or  some such magazine had a do it yourself article on using a using a stereo Amp and a black and white tv to display Lissajous figures. Basically, the left channel went to drive the horizontal, and the right channel drove the vertical. I hooked the directly to the coils on the back of the picture tube. (Oh, more volume, bigger figure.) The first song I put on was Pink Floyd Dark Side of the Moon. I listened with headphones and "watched Pink Floyd Dark Side of the Moon" My friends thought I was an evil Genius but were absolutely amazed. Hi Frequency sound stayed in the center 1 or 2", but the Bass, wow, during a bass only part of the first song I remember a large circle with a loop in it, a continuous line that would smoothly circle around the  diameter of the large circle. They keep talking about "the lunatic was on the Grass". Hey, it was the 70's : )

This reminds me of a summer job I had in collage (around 1980). I programmed on a custom computer/NMR spectrometer combined device. It had an ocilloscope built into it. It came with program that played the game of life on the ocilloscope. It would automaticly adjust the cell size so that the active area would exactly fill the screen. It was fun, but I did not get to play it much. To play it I had to reboot the computer and load the program from paper punched tape 😣. Yes the computer was already old when I worked on it 😅.

Hey Destin,
Your stuff is always great and I appreciate your brand. Because I love you, here are some things I noticed as a video editor and producer.
Fantastic start, spooky low light, really should have saved this for a Halloween special but good introduction!


Okay so the teleportation was a nice surprise, however, you could have capitalized on it more with a better build-up and more clear payoff, like pulling out of the software while the guys are editing the video. Now the dancing begins and your video starts treading water, very off-brand, usually, you get knowledge flowing quickly. The dance and song were too long, and at this point, I'm checking my phone. Now you're sitting down with these guys and we start getting into scary boring territory "Did you start this music genre?".
Ok, finally the default cube in Blender, familiar territory and wow that is cool..... but 6:30, I know you need longer watch time but dang!

Now I will interrupt this long-haired art man's magic with a bad dad joke.
Then he blows everyone mind!


Long short, It just didn't feel like there was a lot of depth, and honestly not much to explain.
Your story should have been about first explaining the premise of the oscilloscope (as you did) + why they exist, and then introduce these gods and let them do their magic.
The flow of the story just kept on getting interrupted.



Thanks for reading this rambling of your fan.
Best,

WOW!! I remember in Middle & High School how 75% + o/what was being "taught" was simply crammed down our gullets with absolutely NO concept of HOW it applied to ANYTHING in real life. It was a "memorize this info so you can pass that test" end of story! For the masses such as myself who are "missing the connections" for retaining information by rote memorization, it was a nightmare. I recall that in my basic Trig. class, the ONLY test I aced was the one in which the concepts were DIRECTLY used in the applications of surveyors (those who use trig. to "plot on a map" the specifics of land ownership, etc.)...EVERYTHING else I strugged through because I had absoutely no frame of reference for application "in the real world" at all. Such applications as an oscilloscope would have made all the difference in the world to me. My studies would have been less "info parroting" and more "knowledge understanding" which would have allowed me to retain the material beyond the upcoming examination. Such a shame...such a waste...such a number of opportunities lost. I can only hope such "real world" applications are presented in the classrooms of today that will make the difference in students' learning. I have learned more from Destin's videos (& further research of concepts he's touched on) than I have learned from any 4 classes in my early schooling years. Keep it up Destin!

If you've ever paid attention to an old CRT television, you'll hear some of them buzzing at a VERY similar frequency to which the sound signals on this video are; when someone moved across the screen in a scene, or the picture suddenly went VERY bright in a scene, the TV speaker on some sets would buzz in sympathy - that's all to do with the raster scanlines and the deflection coils on the yoke at the rear of the CRT (Cathod Ray Tube) - similar but not identical to scopes. A CRT TV uses magnetic fields to deflect the electron beams, whereas a CRT uses electrostatic charge on X/Y deflection plates.

I noticed a natural phenomenon and cant quite understand it. When you swirl water with a spoon or anything like that, the internal whirlpool pulses. I have come to 2 possible theories with my genius friends. 1) they believe its a problem of superposition (the way waves interact with each other) and that as it moves back and forth, the difference in wave height crossing an area causes a difference in height at the middle. 2) my theory is based in centrifugal forces. As objects rotate about a focal point, they actually push perpendicular to the radius and an external force pushes them to stay in a circular pattern. The rotation of the water causes friction which slows the water. Water being a fluid would fill the whirlpool, and when the mass of a rotating object moves toward the focal point, it spins faster, forcing the water to push back out, creating a pulse effect.

My thought to test it is to use 2 identical motors spinning at different speeds in identical water amounts and identical glasses. If you measure the height of change in the whirlpool, then the equivalent amount of change would mean its based on the friction, a different amount of change could mean that the speed of the waves would make superposition the answer.
